the most common definitions that I found states that a service mesh is a dedicated infrastructure layer for
facilitating communications between micro services when we first considered
a service mesh the landscape at Nordstrom looked like this each of the service teams owns
their own tech stack and the apps were built with a variety of tools and languages when teams have to factor in
the configuration and management of these tools they are wasting valuable time that could be better spent handling
business requirements as the engineering
platform team we knew that we could help standardizing these areas that you see in grey tracing service discovery

priorities are met so what are our core priorities we need to make our
applications and services highly available so they can serve our customers and employees with minimal
disruption we cannot just been accustomed er experience by taking hours
to bring our site back up on line consistency and observability is also
key we also need to make a smooth experience for our developers - on board
by - using our service and to offer them access to metrics and logs so they will
not have to configure it themselves we need to offer clear benefits so that our
developers teams want and asked to use a service rather than be forced to onboard
it's a necessity that we can handle traffic spikes with minimal overhead and
still be operational we hold two big events each here our anniversary and holiday sale in
addition to these events there are numerous small events for product launches latency is a critical
metric especially during these major sales and our footprint needs to be small last but not least securing
communications is hard how many of you have had an outage due to an expired cert you'll be shy that's happened to us
too one of the biggest pain points we heard from our developers is how much
they have to keep track of the certificates we need we needed to secure communications between our internal

so what environment should we focus our priorities on when we started down this
path last year we had to understand our what these environments were and where

6,000 production ec2 instances running with numbers like these we couldn't
focus our efforts in all of these environments our mindset was to ultimately craft a solution that would
work for our services that run on the cloud as well as on-premises specifically in our kubernetes clusters
we anticipated that the majority of our services in the future will be deployed
indicates to give you an idea our during our anniversary sale this past July we

how do we go about finding a solution we considered a wide variety of options including spending months designing and
building our own solution from scratch but why we engineer what's already been
created so we scrapped our solution and looked the options that we could either
buy or looked towards the open source community to use an open source project
would allow us to quickly reliably and economically implement a solution to

environment it would also give us engineers a chance to contribute and collaborate with teams outside of
Nordstrom but we did have other things to consider besides how performant and secure a
project is being a large enterprise we needed to look at the number of

our company's company's values is to contribute back to the community and
this gives us engineers a chance to have that sense of accomplishment - so what
do we have on the table among the options that we looked at where sto Aspen mesh and Link Rd it was great to

configurations and testing parameters but ultimately they were all good choices for us but we chose linker D so
link Rd is described as an ultra-light service mesh for kubernetes it gives you
observability reliability and security without requiring any code changes the
performance tests we conducted here what for scalability and load testing our benchmark we used a
benchmarking tool called work to through which we looked at two use cases an above average daily workload and an
anniversary load the latency numbers that you see here are for p90 the test
for the above average daily load were run at 500 requests per second at a thousand concurrent connections
resulting in a latency of three point seven zero milliseconds the test for the
anniversary load was run at five thousand requests per second also at a thousand concurrent connections
resulting in a latency of four point two three milliseconds additionally even
running at a large scale the pod memory usage does not exceed baseline since we
ran these tests our load testing numbers have risen significantly but lickity has certainly met our requirements as being
a lightweight proxy that fits into our roadmap for the future so who gets to

most of my team was brand new to the kubernetes ecosystem and we found ourselves in the position of needing to

about what is kubernetes so the description you see here has a lot of keywords that i've highlighted that
stood out to us as developers so it's portable extensible open-source declarative and can automation so given
nor some situation this description appealed to us we had been breaking up large monolith services for years there
is a desire to increase developer productivity through the use of CI CD automation for our services and we also
wanted to have a common platform for our service teams to use so they can focus on delivering features and not worry
about things like certificates there's always a desire to reduce costs and using or packing as many services as we
can onto an instance is one of those ways to reduce some costs so we've
learned that kubernetes is a platform for managing containers so now what we had to do is figure out what a container
was and once we learned about containers when you get to know a bit about the kubernetes networking model and on and
on and on and it felt like we could get lost in all these technologies so in addition to these various
technologies that we needed to learn there are a few other dragons we need it to slay we had to learn and become familiar with new terminology things
like pods deployments replica sets cluster rolls web hooks even words that we're already used to using like
services and endpoints were being used in a new way for these the kubernetes documentation we found is really well
done and it helped us learn immensely as we were going through this process so in addition to this new terminology there a
whole set of new tools to learn cube CTL mini cube even go was new for us finally
we needed to figure out how we could deploy test and development clusters so that we didn't bring down anything in
production so we started with mini cube as most people do and while mini cube is certainly great we needed something that
was more closely related to our actual environment that we're going to be deploying to so we needed to work with
our kubernetes team to figure out how we can run these clusters in our AWS
account at nordstrom we use a multiple account model for AWS and that means each team has their own a DBS account so
in order to make these changes we needed to talk with yet another team in our enterprise about how we could get the
appropriate access permissions to resources also we had cost concerns so
we were going to be spinning up new clusters in our accounts and there were some concerns about how much that would
cost we ended up figuring out that we could spin up and down clusters on a daily basis so we could keep those costs down
our existing kubernetes team has a ton of tooling already in place to deploy their development clusters to their
accounts but we needed to work with them closely to adapt their tooling for our needs so after many hours reading
documentation watching videos and tutorials we we decided that we were
ready so bring on the service mesh so now that we've come up to speed with
kubernetes it's time to install and run the service mesh but first we're going to talk a little bit about how the
linker d-- works you can see here an architecture diagram that shows the various components that make up linker D
on the top you've got the control plane it has components for things like aggregating telemetry and metrics it
provides a user facing vi4 their dashboard and the command-line tools and also there's a service that's
particularly of interest to us that we'll talk about a little bit later so the link you the identity service that is responsible for issuing certificates
the data plane at the bottom consists of the site card proxy that is injected into each kubernetes pod in the service
mesh the sidecar proxy injection typically includes an init container that is responsible for writing the IP
tables for the pod these rules are configured so that the linker de proxy can intercept all the outgoing traffic
and incoming traffic and this is how they're able to add their features like MT LS traffic observability load
balancing and things like that so now that we know a little bit about liquidy let's go ahead and install it so we went
to the getting started website we do what most people do found the instructions to install linker D it looks like installing linker D is easy
it says so right there so let's give it a go so first we're going to run the
install link or D command and we're going to see what happens when we do that so we see some services being
created we've got the identity service being created this great weave this is a service that's responsible for issuing
certificates we're going to see some more services created we've got the controller and the proxy injector that's
going to help us inject our proxies and a whole bunch more resources were created about 45 more in this particular
case so let's take a look and see what happens so we're going to take a look at
our source mesh pods so this was our
first problem here it says no resources found although it just told me that it created about 48 resources so we need to
do we need to figure out what's going on so we're gonna look at our deployments and sure enough none of our deployments are ready so we need to drill down and
figure out why so we're gonna take a look at our replicas sets and our deployments to see if there's any kubernetes events that can help us
figure out what's going on so it looks like we are unable to create a replica
set because of some various failures apparently we're not able to validate against upon security policy we can't
run as root this net admin capability we can't have that and there's net rock capability we can't use that either so what is a pod
security policy and what is net admin and net rock we just want to install our service mesh at the time we had no clue
what any of this meant since we hadn't seen any of these errors on a test clusters so the initial failure to
install linker D was definitely surprised for us and it presented us with their first real challenge how are
we going to install linker D on our cluster and why did this work in our test environment have any of you been in
this situation task to implement something that was supposed to be easy but then at the very first step ran into
roadblocks so now to be fair these instructions will definitely work for most clusters and most teams but
apparently our Norseman production clusters are configured a little bit differently than most instructions assume and the main difference is that
they're configured for the highest security so over time our kubernetes
team has put in place security measures than include pod security policies LDAP access control and the principle of
least privilege these measures along with many others secure a cluster for the hundreds of service teams using it
so our first challenge was realizing that we're not cluster administrators and really this shouldn't have been a
surprise we should have known this but it was a surprise for us at the time we also don't want to be cluster administrators we want to keep the
closer administrators the count to a minimum due to the types of data present
in the cluster and the types of communication between our services so not being administrators means that we
can't just create cluster roles and modify policies in order to make our service mesh work so if we need a
cluster wide resource or if we need to modify something we need to talk with our kubernetes team we need to reach out
to them and we need to tell them what they need or what we need and they help us get what we want they ask us some
very tough questions and they look over every line of llam√≥ that we submit and they ensure that we're only getting what
we asked for and what we need the security of our cluster is a top priority so the second challenge was
figuring out what to do with this pod security policy a pod security policy is one way that a cluster administrators
have controlled our security requirements for the they can control things like port numbers that are allowed user IDs and
specific linux capabilities that are allowed so the errors we were seeing meant that we are in violation of this
pod security policy specifically that must run as non-root property and the request for net admin and that raw
capabilities so if you remember the linker D proxy is IP tables rules to
intercept incoming and outgoing traffic well in order to write these IP tables rules a process needs to be route or
more specifically a process needs to have the capabilities captain net admin and this capability allows users to
administer the firewall modify routing tables bind to any address and generally other things that shouldn't be allowed
in a multi-tenant cluster for most users if the user had this capability and they
wanted to they could likely inspect all traffic on from coming in and out of the pod or even on the node so there's a
very good reason why our team has denied this capability for us so because the
controls are linked to service accounts and kubernetes and not pods if we granted a security exception for a
service account than anybody with that service account can also have this capability and we didn't want that so
now we had to figure out how to the users link ID given this pod security
policy so to do that we worked with a vibrant open source community
surrounding linker D we chatted with the link of the engineers and our own kubernetes cluster team to figure out a
solution that would work for us so during our discussions it was suggested that a CNI plugin would be one way of
solving our issue this would allow us to run a custom binary whenever a pod is created and that binary would be able to
write the IP tables rules for that pod because the CNI plugin process runs on
the note itself there are no special capabilities that you need to give a service account and the pods no longer
need to ask for net admin or net raw so the other appealing feature of the CNI plugin is that we can chain them
together and so our new plugin would be able to move in to where the other existing plugins that we had in place so
we went for it and created the cni plugin I don't know how many of you have ever tried to Krita C&I plugin but for us i remember
this particular story when we were just simply trying to verify that what we had
written that was going to work and because you know we're running in a cluster on a remote machine the typical
application developer tools like d bugs and breakpoints of stuff weren't available to us as far as we could tell
so we had to figure out another way so we put in print statements right that's what people do so as we were doing this
our plugin wasn't working and we didn't really understand why and i remember inviting a colleague over to look over
my shoulder and to him everything look great - it turns out that CNI plugins
communicate via the standard in standard out using J a specific JSON payload and
what we were doing was putting our print statements into the standard out and that wasn't valid JSON so our plugins
down the chain we're not working now it was interesting because we finally
figured this out but it you know if you if we would have read the documentation for sinaia plug is it's all right there it says use standard error so when we
decided to use standard eret everything was working just fine after all so luckily for us there's a lot of
reference material out there thanks to open source communities around sto and calico so in short order we were able to
create a linker DC and I plug in to meet our needs and contribute that source back to the linker D project so there's
just one more issue for us regarding the scene I plug in and that was how to get it deployed on our nodes so our
kubernetes cluster knows come up and down constantly all the time because our kubernetes team is doing upgrades and
maintenance often so because of this there's a very small chance that when a
pod comes online it will give scheduled on a new node and it has a linker D proxy but that's before the CNI plugin
has written the IP tables so that means even though the pot had only could be proxy it would not be a part of the
service mesh so we had to figure out a way to work around this and so because we couldn't use the typical daemon set
installation that you would usually see with the CNI plugin so it took some more time talking with the kubernetes team
and we were able to basically bake the the plugin directly onto our base image for our notes and so finally we had a
solution that would allow us to install linker D onto our clusters but we're still not quite done there are
two more security requirements that we had to meet we had to be able to audit all of the certificates that our service
mesh was using and we also had to make sure that they were all signed by the Nordstrom certificate authority so
remember that link Rd has that identity service that is responsible for creating and issuing certificates to the proxies
since that service typically handles all the certificate creation and generation
automatically using its own self signed certificates we couldn't meet these requirements out of the box and we
needed to figure out a way to get these certificates from our Nordstrom certificate authority that we already
had in place so we chatted with the link OD engineers some more and we decided to go ahead and code up a solution for us
that would have the link Rd identity service reach out to the Amazon private certificate authority we had to get
those certificates and we've been using the solution for a few months now and it
works great for us it turns out that this particular approach is it actually going to be merged into the upstream
code and that's okay the link for the engineers are going to use another open source project sort manager to use for
custom certificates and I think overall for the community you know this will be a better solution because we'll be able
to support more than just our particular AWS certificate authority it also means
that we are itching to contribute back to any cert manager pour request or
issue that needs our help and so stay tuned for that work so now that we've
